731949f-a.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel.]
731949f-a.text:
Coney Island's beach and boardwalk seen from the Atlantic. At the
left is the ncw Half-Moon Hotel.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

731951f-a.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel.]
731951f-a.text:
(1)
A general view of the beach, showing the dense throng of bathers
and sunbathers. In the distance is the Half-Moon Hotel.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A good view of a Coney Island crowd. Oddly enough, this is a
week-day crowd. It is difficult to attempt to picture the
scene on a weekend.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
A supurb marine photograph, which gives a good idea of the
terrifio mob at Coney Island Beach. In the background,
sharply silhouetted against the sky, is the Half-Moon Hotel.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

731952f-b.text:

Sunbathers on Coney Island Beach.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
~~e.3

August 8, 1932.

(3)
An extremely dense portion of the beach, showing the ocean and,
dimly in the distance, a small sailing vessel.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODDUCTIONS.

731954f-b.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers and vendors.]
731954f-b.text:
(1)
Sunbathers at Coney Island Beach who, with clothes on hickory
limb, are not going near the water.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A small portion of the beach. Notice the flower vendor peddling
his wares. As this is a week-day, the crowd is not very large.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
More sun-bathers. The pretzel vendor is trying to create a
demand for her wares. The pretzels will, of course, create a
thirst which can be quenched with lemonade (beer is not yet legal),
the lemonade and sea-air will cause a hunger to be satisfied
with hot-dogs, hamburger and onions, and ice-cream, which
will cause a stomachache to be subdued with bicarbonate of soda.
August 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

732019f-b.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - Coney Island Pavilion.
732019f-b.text:
(1)
Coney Island Beach and a pavillion. At the right is a life-
guard's stand, and in the background is a bathing pier.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCIIONS.
(2)
Beach and sunbathersw. An ice-cream peddler does his bit to
boost the sale of bicarbonate of soda.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
A general view of the beach, showing piers and the ocean at
the right, and a portion of the boardwalk at the left.
August 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

731956f-a.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers.]
731956f-a.text:
(1)
An excellent action photograph of a man being tossed from a
blanket, Coney Ialand Beach.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
Another victim goes aloft -- this time a giri.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
A second girl points her toes skyward.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

731957f-b.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Sunbathers and swimmers.]
731957f-b.text:
(1)
A holiday crowd at Coney Island Beach. In the centre someone
is being tossed from a blanket.
July 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
Beach, ocean, and piers at Coney Island. Although this picture
was made on a Saturday, the crowd is not very dense. Later
in the summer, as the days get hotter, it will be difficult
to see the beach at all, for the crowds.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
Beach, swimmers, and sunbathers at Coney Island.
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

731960f-b.title: Islands - Coney Island beach - [Half-Moon Hotel - Riegelmann boardwalk.]
731960f-b.text:
(1)
A view of the Beach, When approximately a million people congregate
to enjoy themselves. In the background, is the Reigelmann (Coney Island)
Boardwalk. At the left, is the 14-story Half-Moon Hotel, on the north
side of the boardwalk, between 29th and 28th Streets.
July 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A continuation of No. 1, (Coney Island).
JulY 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
Another view of Plate No. 1. (Coney Island).
July 4, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
